citation.article-title: Fusobacterium alocis sp. nov. and Fusobacterium sulci sp. nov. from the human gingival sulcus.

p.s: Description of Fusobacterium alocis sp. nov.
Fusobacterium alocis (a'lo.kis. Gr. n. alox a furrow; N.L. gen. n. alocis of a furrow, referring to its isolation from a crevice of the gums)
Cells are gramnegative, nonsporeforming, obligately anaerobic rods, 0.4 to 0.7 by 1.5 to 7.0 μm, with rounded to tapered ends.
They occur singly, in pairs, or occasionally in short chains.
Of 117 strains, 6 have slow twitching or end-over-end type of motility, but flagella are not detected.
Surface colonies on anaerobic blood agar plates are pinpoint to 1.0 mm, circular, entire, flat to low convex, translucent to transparent, shiny, smooth, and nonhemolytic.
No internal colony structure is visible.
The optimum temperature for growth is 37°C, at which growth is only moderate at best.
Slight growth occurs at 30 and 45°C; there is little or no growth at 25°C.
Growth can be stimulated by the addition of rabbit serum (Anal concentration, 10 to 15% [vol/vol]) and cocarboxylase (final concentration, 5 μg/ml).
Most strains grow better in an atmosphere of 10% CO2-90% N2 than of 100% CO2.
Cultures in peptone-yeast extract-glucose (PYG) bruth have a fine granular sediment and no turbidity after incdbation for 5 to 7 days.
The final pH of cultures in PYG broth and in basal medium incubated in a CO2-N2 atmosphere is 6.8 to 7.1; under 100% CO2, the final pH of each is 5.9 to 6.1.
Although little or no gas is formed in PYG deep agar cultures, abundant H2 is detected in the headspaces of broth cultures when there is sufficient growth.
No H2S is detected in sulfide-indole-motility medium (BBL Microbiology Systems).

No acid is produced from adonitol, amygdalin, L-arabinose, cellobiose, dextrin, dulcitol, meso-erythritol, esculin, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, glycerol, glycogen, inositol, indlin, lactose, maltose, D-mannitol, D-mannose, melezitose, melibiose, pectin, raffinose, rhamnose, D-(-)ribose, salicin, D-sorbitol, L-sorbose, starch, sucrose, trehalose, or D-xylose.
Indole, acetylmethylcarbinol, catalase, lecithinase, lipase, urease, oxidase, and deoxyribonuclease are not produced.
Esculin, starch, and hippurate are not hydrolyzed.
Nitrate is not reduced; neither resazurin nor neutral red is reduced.
There is no reaction in milk and no digestion of gelatin or chopped meat.
The products of fermentation in PYG broth are small to moderate amounts of butyrate and acetate.
Pyruvate, DL-lactate, D-gluconate, and DL-threonine are not utilized.

All tested strains are susceptible to chloramphenicol (12 μg/ml), clindamycin (1.6 μg/ml), erythromycin (3 μg/ml), and tetracycline (6 μg/ml); 1 of 20 strains tested is resistant to penicillin (2 U/ml).
The principal habitat of F. alocis is the human gingival sulcus.
It has been isolated from a submandibular abscess and from a mouth ulcer.
The type strain of F. alocis is VPI D40B-5 (=ATCC 35896).
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the DNA of this strain is 34 mol%.
